image.altText: Anne Clifton, a woman with wispy grey hair, stands in front of two large colourful vases.

props.synopsis: This Tasmanian artist's work has been acquired by the prestigious Victoria and Albert Museum in London — the significance is yet to be realised, but a local legacy is already taking shape.

title.children: Fire, paint and 'slight anarchy': Artist blown on to the world stage with international acquisition

image.altText: A man sitting in a chair

props.synopsis: Australia's far-right movement has been buoyed by a wave of recent protests against mass immigration, with some saying the rallies were the "biggest thing that's happened in conservative and nationalist politics for a hundred years".

title.children: Far-right figures want to see shift away from Australia's 'legacy' politicians

image.altText: A man gestures as he looks at camera.

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian woman who was allegedly the subject of a dispute that left one man dead and another accused of his murder says she has almost no memory of the evening because she had used "a lot of drugs".

title.children: Witness denies remembering night that left friend dead and housemate accused of murder

image.altText: A slow shutter speed blurs the movement of two horses training at a racetrack.

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian racing integrity investigation finds a number of racing stewards, including the acting chief thoroughbred steward, placed more than 200 bets on races across a two-and-a-half-year period.

title.children: Stewards placed hundreds of bets on Tasmanian races, investigation finds

image.altText: A close-up shot of a woman's pregnant belly, with two hands cradling the bump

props.synopsis: A proposal by the Tasmanian government to introduce a public homebirth model has been welcomed by those in the sector.

title.children: Tasmanian women may soon be able to access public homebirths

image.altText: A statue holding a set of scales on a blue background

props.synopsis: Finding out that remains of a loved one ended up part of a museum collection without permission would be nothing short of shocking. An inquest into the actions of UTAS's RA Rodda Pathology Museum has found that's exactly what happened. Airlie Ward talks with reporter Loretta Lohberger.

title.children: TassieCast: How did a museum illegally collect human remains for decades?

image.altText: Slices of body parts covered in Perspex and put on display on walls.

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian coroner has released his findings from an investigation into 177 human specimens held in the collection of a university museum without the consent or knowledge of families.

title.children: Body parts taken without consent for museum display, coroner finds

image.altText: Cut potatoes which show evidence of Mop Top Virus

props.synopsis: Biosecurity Tasmania is working to trace the origins of the two potatoes, as potato mop-top virus continues to spread through Tasmania.

title.children: Mop-top virus found in potatoes bought from Tasmanian retail stores

image.altText: A homemade gun with metal pipes strapped into a round barrel.

props.synopsis: While they may look strange, even toy-like, 3D-printed weapons can still be deadly — and they are high on the watchlist for police in Tasmania.

title.children: Wonky 'scrap metal' and 3D-printed guns seized by police

image.altText: Macaque monkeys grooming.

props.synopsis: Tasmanian ratepayers will spend around $60,000 to send councillors and senior staff to a Japanese sister city that gave Launceston its macaque monkeys. One ratepayer believes it is "nothing more than a junket holiday".

title.children: 'Living in another world': Council's $60k trip to a Japanese city at ratepayers' expense

image.altText: Three people smile for a selfie in front of the burning Singha Durbar building

props.synopsis: A calm has fallen on Nepal's streets after days of violence and chaos. But leaders of the gen Z protest movement say the work's not done.

title.children: Why Nepal's gen Z protesters say they 'have not yet won the war'

image.altText: A man wearing a black suit and glasses stands at a pedestal giving a speech in front of a blue backdrop labelled "NATO"

props.synopsis: NATO announces plans to beef up the defence of Europe's eastern flank two days after Poland shot down Russian drones that had violated its airspace.

title.children: NATO to reinforce eastern defences after 'reckless' Russian drone incursion

image.altText: A woman wearing glasses and a shawl sits looking neutrally at the camera

props.synopsis: Sushila Karki garnered widespread support from many young Nepalese people who took to the streets in anger over government corruption.

title.children: Nepal's new PM Sushila Karki sworn in after gen Z protests

image.altText: A blurred out image of a woman looking into a mirror.

props.synopsis: Dr Stan Theodoros is facing disciplinary proceedings, lodged by Queensland's health ombudsman, in the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal (QCAT).

title.children: Brisbane doctor accused of performing 'sexually motivated' checks

image.altText: A young Dau bounces a baskteball on an outside court

props.synopsis: Last weekend, Dau Akueng, 15, and Chol Achiek, 12, were fatally stabbed on their way home from basketball in Melbourne's western suburbs. The pair are being remembered by those who knew them for who they were, not just for how they tragically died.

title.children: Two boys killed in Melbourne's west remembered for ambition and kindness

image.altText: various views of Sydney Harbour from Woolwich marina and Kelly's Bush

props.synopsis: Locals have argued if the expansion in Woolwich were to go ahead it "would be like putting a bus station in the middle of a children's playground".

title.children: The fight over privately-owned Sydney marina's expansion plans

image.altText: A Virgin and Qantas plane flying in opposite directions with two velocity and frequent flyer credit cards in the foreground.

props.synopsis: Millions of Australians are signed up to airline loyalty schemes, but a new global ranking finds travellers are getting poorer value than from overseas carriers.

title.children: Hidden risks of frequent flyer points and one traveller's $5,000 lesson

image.altText: An elderly lady on sitting on a walker, having a cup of tea on a verandah

props.synopsis: Elderly residents of Porepunkah have had their home nurse visits cancelled as alleged police killer Dezi Freeman remains at large.

title.children: Dezi Freeman manhunt leaves elderly people without in-home care

image.altText: A man wearing a mask carefully excavates sediment.

props.synopsis: It was on a sweltering morning in 2018 in a cave in northern Vietnam when Chris Stimpson and his team uncovered what may be the oldest cold case murder in South-East Asia.

title.children: Evidence points to remains being South-East Asia's earliest known homicide victim

image.altText: Two flares from a tower light up the night sky.

props.synopsis: Seven years after it was first mooted, the extension of Australia's biggest gas project could not have landed at a more critical juncture for the nation's climate credentials.

title.children: What Woodside's gas project extension means for Australia's climate record

image.altText: Jai Newcombe clenches his fists and roars to the heavens

props.synopsis: Hawthorn will face Geelong in a preliminary final after knocking minor premier Adelaide out with a 34-point semifinal victory.

title.children: Hawks soar into prelim final as Crows suffer historic double-defeat

image.altText: A man holding his hat and smiling at the camera.

props.synopsis: Legendary Yolŋu actor David Gulpilil held an ambition throughout his career to share a part of himself and his culture that the world had never seen before. A new documentary does exactly that.

title.children: New documentary brings David Gulpilil's dying wish to life

image.altText: A man and woman embrace at an airport

props.synopsis: The workers arrived home to emotional scenes as many consider never returning to the US following the raids which have caused serious tension between the longstanding allies.

title.children: 'Nobody is going to stay': South Korean workers return home after US raids

image.altText: A group sits in front of a row of flags

props.synopsis: Despite pressure from Beijing, Pacific leaders have backed Taiwan's right to attend the Pacific Islands Forum.

title.children: Pacific leaders reject China's push to exclude Taiwan from regional forum

image.altText: An old photo of a wildlife keeper feeding a large saltwater crocodile

props.synopsis: The Great Barrier Reef and the Daintree Rainforest are must-sees for millions worldwide, but it was once so difficult to get to Cairns that promoters resorted to gimmicks.

title.children: Crocs, planes and a Hollywood hit (well, almost) put Cairns on the map

image.altText: Gout Gout flexes after winning a race.

props.synopsis: The 2025 World Athletics Championships in Tokyo sees Australia's largest-ever team tackle the best athletes on the planet. Here are the key events you won't want to miss.

title.children: When does Gout Gout run and the other key events at the World Championships

image.altText: Brad Battin speaks to media at Parliament House in Melbourne. He stands in front of a dark background.

props.synopsis: More than a year out from the next state election, Opposition Leader Brad Battin is making a pitch to Victorians to make them safer. His policy centrepiece is 'Jack's Law', to give police greater powers to randomly search people for weapons.

title.children: Victorian opposition plan to increase powers to search people for weapons

image.altText: Wilco Kelderman and Jai Hindley riding together in the La Vuelta.

props.synopsis: Australia's Jai Hindley is still in with a chance of claiming a top-three spot at the Vuelta a España ahead of its conclusion this weekend.

title.children: Hindley in contention for Vuelta podium finish

image.altText: A trophy being touched by a pair of hands with gloves on.

props.synopsis: Teams in the Hunter Central Coast AFL play for a trophy that was first contested in 1888 and holds plenty of memories for grand final winners.

title.children: Two teams to battle it out for the oldest trophy in Australian sport

image.altText: Two men and a woman stand before the back of a truck, the men grin and the woman doesn't. One man has his arm around the woman.

props.synopsis: At the peak of their success, Big Thief faced a major emotional rupture that reshaped the group from the inside out. Now, they've returned with their sixth album, shaped by deep creative trust and a renewed commitment to collaboration.

title.children: How Big Thief turned loss into laughter on their new album

image.altText: Helly Easther-Smith looks at the camera inside a holiday rental.

props.synopsis: After a cold winter, a warm spring is often a welcome time for towns that rely heavily on tourism. But for regional South Australian coastal communities hit hard by the ongoing algal bloom, there's a feeling of concern about what should be a busy period.

title.children: SA coastal businesses concerned about algal bloom impact on summer tourism

image.altText: An aerial picture of a lagoon inside a narrow atoll.

props.synopsis: China says its newly announced reserve is about preserving coral, but the Philippines says it is another step towards Bejing tightening its claim on a contested, strategic area of the South China Sea.

title.children: China announces new nature reserve in middle of contested, strategic waters

image.altText: Person smiles slightly with closed mouth. They have short dark hair and stand against a plain background.

props.synopsis: In their latest book, author and human rights lawyer Keio Yoshida draws on their personal experience and legal expertise to demonstrate the importance of sharing queer stories.

title.children: Keio Yoshida's new book fights for more considered recognition of queer lives

image.altText: Giorgio Armani waves as he walks down a runway smiling.

props.synopsis: Giorgio Armani's will has surprised fashion watchers as it contains instructions to gradually sell off his company to a luxury brand or seek a listing on the stock market, in seeming contrast to his fiercely independent stance throughout his career.

title.children: Armani's will surprises with instructions to sell brand or list on stock market

image.altText: A man wearing a dark shirt stands outside a courthouse

props.synopsis: Neo-Nazi leader Thomas Sewell has been ordered to serve 200 hours of community service after being found guilty of intimidating a police officer.

title.children: Neo-Nazi Thomas Sewell found guilty of intimidating police officer
